comment.author: 8822983@N08
comment._content: Wow, great perspectives! What an eye!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Wonderful picture and perspectives - it reminds me of an Escher print with the almost impossible bridge. When you know there is a steep hill on the right with a road cut through the rock (Argyle Cut) along the bottom of the picture, it begins to make sense. The area has changed considerably since then. Slum clearance after the bubonic plague in 1900, and the approach roads for the Sydney Harbour Bridge flattened the right side of the street. The corner house (with penthouse) at centre is no longer there, but the next house is - a top floor window is now the front door, due to s street level rise of about two metres (to raise the bridge?). See Google street view: maps.google.com.au/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The previous photo of Cambridge Street is dated "Aug 1901".  The shadows and lighting are similar to this, though a reverse view.  And there is that advert (see note) for disinfectant - I would say that this is also August 1901. About 9am !

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: A print of this photograph appears in State Records NSW here: www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3683566916/

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Beachcomber/ BobMeade, are the two terraces (off in the distance and on the immediate right of the centre building) those which stood on The Rocks Archeological dig site which has been now preserved under the YMCA building?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] The short answer is no - those two four terraces are about where the current Australian Hotel is, or possibly under Cumberland Street. The archeological dig was a block or so further south This area is extremely confusing because Cumberland and Gloucester Streets were combined and straightened since this wonderful photo. There used to be three bridges over the Argyle Cut; now only two. Princes Street is under the southern Harbour Bridge approach. 1895 interactive map showing the streets as they were - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... Google Street view - almost unrecognisable.

comment.author: 89239358@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Does anyone have an old photo of Princes St before it was demolished? My 3x grt grandfather, William Swadling emigrated from England at the end of 1838 and lived there, apparently near the Wesleyan Chapel, for the first two years with his family.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/89239358@N03] @ robbiemac53 - State Records NSW has a fair collection c.1900 - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photosear... . Do a "simple keyword search" for 'princes'. The Wesleyan Chapel is shown on this 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=... . This map of Princes St between Essex and Argyle Sts may also be of interest - gallery.records.nsw.gov.au/wp-content/gallery/darling-har...
